source: This idiom originates from a story about Ji Kang, a famous scholar and musician of the Wei and Jin dynasties. When his son Ji Shao was young, someone praised him to his father, saying he was 'outstanding like a wild crane standing among a flock of chickens.' The phrase later became a fixed idiom to describe someone who stands out prominently from the ordinary crowd.
meaning: It describes a person of outstanding talent, virtue, or appearance who stands out conspicuously from the ordinary people around them, just as a tall, elegant crane would among a group of common chickens.
usage: Used to praise someone who is exceptionally talented, virtuous, or distinguished compared to their peers. It carries a strongly complimentary and admiring tone. It is commonly used in both formal and informal contexts to describe individuals in academic, professional, or social settings who excel far beyond others.
